div.p: Jetty is a HTTP server, HTTP client, and Servlet container with small foot print, embeddability, enterprise scalability and advanced asynchronous features.

First created in 1995, Jetty has benefitted from input from a vast user community and consistent and focused development by a stable core of lead developers. On the 24th of March, 2009, the Jetty-7 code base was converted to org.eclipse.jetty package space and checked into the Eclipse Jetty SVN repository.

Jetty is now in incubation at the Eclipse Foundation. Once established as an Eclipse project, it will be dual-licensed, maintaining its current Apache 2.0 license, and adding the Eclipse Public License. Jetty may be used and distributed under the terms of either. It is free for commercial use and distribution.

p.b: Full commercial support, training and development services for Jetty and Jetty-based projects are available from Webtide.

ul.li: a stand-alone traditional web server for static and dynamic content
a dynamic content server behind a dedicated HTTP server such as Apache using mod_proxy
an embedded component within a Java application

div.div:
Simple We want to make Jetty easy to understand and use:
Configurable using either API or XML
XML file syntax is a straightforward mapping from the API operating on POJOs
Minimal number of lines required to embed a Jetty instance

Scalable In asynchronous Web 2.0 type applications using techniques such as AJAX, connections stay open longer than when serving static pages, and thread and memory requirements can escalate drastically. With Jetty...
Performance degrades gracefully under stress for high quality of service
Handle large user loads and long-lived sessions with continuations, while working within the framework of existing web specifications
Integrate with available clustering options such as WADI and Terracotta

Efficient A lot of effort goes into optimizing Jetty's performance and crafting the code so as to make the footprint as small as possible:
The core is kept small; extra functionality is in optional jars and dependencies are kept to a minimum
Scalability is a key concern
Performance degrades gracefully under stress

Embeddable Jetty is designed to be a good component:
Usage of dependency injection and inversion of control patterns

Pluggable Jetty is architected for pluggability:
Use a provided implementation
Code your own using the provided interfaces and abstract classes

ul.li: shipped with products to provide out-of-the-box usability eg Tapestry, Liferay
distributed on CDs with books to make examples and exercises ready-to-run
incorporated into applications as a HTTP transport eg JXTA, MX4J
integrated as a web container in JavaEE app servers eg JOnAS, Geronimo, JBoss, JFox
included as a component of an application eg Continuum, FishEye, Maven

div.p: The Jetty Powered Page contains more examples from among the tens of thousands of production Jetty instances. Countless more websites and products are based around Jetty, but because Jetty aims to be as unobtrusive as possible, Jetty is invisible!
